comments.commentBody: Just like the iPhone 5? Darn it, Samsung is still "copying" Apple, and outselling them doing it!

Great specs - but the branding and features come off as being over-hyped in the sense that they aren't revolutionary or transformative.  Lots of incremental improvements and experimental features that may or may not be around in the next generation of product.  Also, they need to find an American to write some of their ad copy... most of it sounds like they fed Korean prose into Google Translator.

With Bluetooth, why does the size of the phone matter anymore? I wish Apple had a larger screen, like 5" because I mostly use the browser and I don't want something as big as an iPad Mini.

There's bluetooth in the car and near my desk and in my ear, so I don't have to hold the phone itself up to my ear when I make a call. I have an iPhone 4S (and had two previous models). The iPhone 5 is a huge disappointment to me because it just isn't much different from the 4S. Just a retread. And Siri is an absolute failure.

Apple needs to start innovating. I don't think Tim Cook knows what he's doing. Big problems with all the roll-outs with this company in the fall of 2012.

Personally, I like the size and feel of the iPhone 5 - it's perfect for phoning. If Apple could increase the display size without changing the overall size or shape of the device by, say, moving the home button to the side and using the vacated area for more display, I'd be all for it. But otherwise I usually go to a device with more real estate. e.g. iPad, for my content viewing

Apple should relax. How much of the market do they need? They have billions that they don't seem to know what to do with, so they should relax and take time to improve existing products (like the map app) and introduce something new like the iWatch. The last thing they should do is downscale or upscale in order to capture every last customer in the world. The apple brand needs to be protected as the high-end offering in the market place with excellent customer support. Samsung is already gimmicking itself to irrelevance. Apple's biggest asset is that its customers feel that the company cares about them by providing good support, and mountains of documentation. For example, continual upgrades of the iOS at no additional cost. Relax and keep the faith, remember Steve is watching.

However, it too will probably outlive us both.

Both of these institutions, like the well-evolved organisms they are, have plenty of defenses that are arrayed to resist change.

And why would that deter someone? Nobody is going to come to your aid, even if you shout fire....

Putting your head in the sand or screaming in fear when the wolf is in the fold is too late.....

As for the U.S. Military, the vast bulk of us know the U.S. Constitution well, the National Guardsmen do not... and that would cause a bit of a problem.

Of all the scenarios most likely to lead to civil war over reaching politicians on such things as gun control during a period of civil unrest over deteriorating economic issues is right at the top of the list..

Incidents like what happened in New Orleans keep folks up at night in the Pentagon because the Generals know what the President does not, the troops will not have his back or obey their orders when they are in violation of the Constitution.
It is amusing that anti-gun folks always assume that soldiers and LEO's are on their side.
Fair point ... but as I understand it, none of the proposed additional restrictions would have prevented Newtown ... am I mistaken - which of the proposals would have done so?

At least some of this hesitation to vote for sensible gun regulations by conservatives is an abject fear of the NRA, and that organization's ability to conflate fear. One Republican recently proclaimed that the real reason for the 2nd amendment and the right to bear arms is to protect us against government tyranny. This overlooks the obvious, that this amendment was drafted in the late 18th century when the British and that empire's soldiers really were on American soil. If the government became too tyrannical, and some argue that it has, good luck with defeating the power of the U.S. military, police and national guardsmen.

The second fear is of a random intruder coming into your home in the dead of night, apparently bent on killing everyone in his path. A high unlikely scenario, but if this did play out, for those in remote areas it would seem having a trained dog or alarm system, some of which put out deafening sounds, would be all the deterrent needed.

The problem with the Republican idea is that there is a tiny grain of truth, none of us will ever be fully safe (or fully prepared) from an unexpected attack. The choice is to live in fear, gun under the pillow, or go about our lives and looking for what is good and fulfilling in life. The children of Newtown and so many other innocents deserve our care and these protections, which trump any need for those selfish few bent on having killing weapons.

We can see that these GOP politicians seem to think if they keep up their assault on reality, the public will come to believe their proposals as being valid. We have seen these tactics before in the history of politics. It is an assault on the credibility of the voters to make rational decisions as to what is in their best interest.

Ryan and his minions do not really expect these proposals to go anywhere at present, but it is a sly underhanded attack on the mind of the voters. If they can be brought to doubt their own beliefs these ideas will subvert their personal beliefs, and these proposals will gain support a bit at a time.

In their minds, the election did not invalidate their ideology, it just did not get enough support, so they will just continue to do what they can to get a few more followers. They have their beliefs and no failure of support will get them to change those beliefs. They believe they are right, and those who do not follow them are wrong, no matter the facts.

We can see many of their followers in these comment posts, still repeating the party line, such as the country has to be saved from the Liberals, the country is failing, Obama is ineffective, the Democrats want to spend you into penury, and so on. The "Big Lie" is still with us.

I remember the pain my late father felt when his cries of the Emperor has no clothes were met with derision and ridicule. He possessed neither wealth, power nor fame so what could he know?

A strong central government that enforces the law

Equal treatment for all under the law

A representative government

Workers to keep enough of the fruits of their labor to be free of fear

Workers who are smart and diligent have a good chance to move up the social ladder

The frustrating part of all this is that, as workers get squeezed financially, they become more irrational, tribal and less likely to listen to reason. What I remember about budget deficits is that with a modest increase in taxes and a modest restraint in social programs Bill Clinton, with nary a Republican vote, eliminated the budget deficit and started to work down the national debt. That did not work very well.

I'm definitely sticking with Krugman.

I enjoyed solving this puzzle. The construction was impressive. I agree with Deb that some of the entries were not elegant in the normal way we judge grids, but the idea behind today's puzzle was in the small number of black squares. I normally am a big fan of tricky clues that misdirect; today's puzzle misdirects us by ignoring our expectations with regard to "elegant" entries. The fact that we normally don't expect "imaginativeness"or the plural "recapitulations" means that the surprise came from the grid instead of the clues (in these cases without obscure or trivial facts). I think it's a good thing when puzzles include words I don't expect, even if (and occasionally especially if) the thwarted expectations are characterized in terms of aesthetic judgment.

Polls taken this far in advance are indeed ridiculous but there's a reason they attract so much attention. The general tenor of the Republican Party is that Barack Obama is an illegitimate President -- even the non-birthers feel this way, blaming "star quality" or "votes cast by voters who want 'things'" rather than accepting the 2008 and 2012 results. Democrats felt much the same way about George W. Bush after the 2000 election.

In essence, we have a "permanent campaign" mentality fostered by the extreme divide between the parties. Having held on to the House, the GOP is now concerned only with holding it in 2014 and then recapturing the whole schmeer in 2016. In the interim, they will obstruct whatever Obama wants to do. In this kind of atmosphere, the 2016 polls are indeed important, because they represent the next time what the GOP sees as a massive error can be corrected.

Until we have a President, a House, and a filibuster-proof Senate from the same pary, we will see the party of the "outs" looking to the next election, and doing what it can to prevent serious governance until then.

Things may be about to reverse in the upcoming post-Obama era: the Democrats' look likely to seek their nominee within, an "establishment" choice, while the GOP look to be seeking a non-establishment choice. It reflects where each party has been over the past 2 election cycles.

I'm skeptical of the explanation that suggests that it's in the GOP's political DNA to pick the establishment choice, and it's in the Dems' DNA to pick an outsider. Small # statistics. A lot of early favorites on the Dem. side didn't run (Cuomo '92) or had their candidacies destroyed by a fluke scandal (Hart '88). In an alternate universe, either of them might have won easily. The GOP has simply had more election cycles in which there was an establishment favorite who was running, but it could easily happen for the Dems in 2016 if HRC runs.

I'm also curious about whether there's any useful information in the early general election polls. Not necessarily about who's going to win, but about whether particular candidates in particular matchups have a particular demographic draw, or if they'll cause a strong trend towards their party in specific states.

The early 2016 general election polls by PPP are interesting. Clinton of course does very well, but she makes her strongest gains over Obama's 2012 numbers in the South. "Clinton vs. X" also produces a huge gender gap, and an age differential far less stark than in either of Obama's two elections. (You can see the GOP candidate doing best among voters age 30-45 in some of these matchups.)

Does any of that mean anything for 2016, or does such polling have no real predictive value?

The bishop said: Kill them all; God will know his own. This has been edited and updated to : Kill 'em all, let God sort 'em out. I think that speaks for itself.

And who's talking of flower children?

Gets my vote for most bizarre psychological projection masquerading as a comment.
But why do you seem to view sexual intimacy as "a distraction from devotion to God"...?

Neither Francis nor Christ professed that sin didn't matter. While taking steps to spare the adulterous woman from being stone, Jesus nevertheless admonished her to forsake her sinful practice. Timothy Egan would rather have a pope pretend there was no sin at all — except, of course, owning property.

As for the heretics of the Middle Ages to whom he alludes, they were called the Cathars, and they were a bloody, repressive, and intolerant lot. To tolerate them was to abdicate responsibility for the protection of those who lived in the precincts where they thrived.

Finally, Francis' vaunted simplicity wasn't simply some flower child naïveté. It was a radical attempt to purge himself of all that distracted him from a devotion to God. That meant celibacy as well as poverty.

I've come over time to dislike the endless adulation of Francis. I'd like to think that has less to do with finding his example unacceptable than because I can no longer stand the blind, insipid, dishonest way he's been invoked to excuse every kind of laid-back lassitude advocated by contemporary secularists.
